description: What, if anything, is the secret to extending life? Does our society do enough for its oldest citizens?

title: Mayor Eric Adams Is Stuck on Ideas From 1994 for Crime in 2022
description: Tired “tough on crime” rhetoric is not the solution to crime in 2022.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City understands the assignment: to keep the nation’s largest city safe amid an alarming rise in violent crime. At least 40 of the people shot so far this year in New York were children and teenagers, or one in every 10 shooting victims. One of those children, Kade Lewin, 12, was shot and killed while sitting with relatives in a parked car in Brooklyn.

title: Premier of British Virgin Islands Arrested on Drug Trafficking Charges in U.S.
description: Andrew Fahie, the elected head of government of the small Caribbean territory, has been charged with conspiracy to import at least five kilograms of a cocaine mixture and conspiracy to launder money.
content: The premier of the British Virgin Islands was arrested on Thursday in the Miami area on drug trafficking and money laundering charges, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Christie’s to Sell a Dinosaur That Inspired the ‘Jurassic Park’ Raptor
description: The auction house says this is the first-ever sale of a Deinonychus, the species on which the ‘velociraptor’ in the 1993 movie was based.
content: Many people know them as agile bipedal dinosaurs with menacing claws and scrunched-up arms, hunting children through a kitchen in “Jurassic Park.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Jacques Perrin, Soft-spoken Film Star and Producer, Is Dead at 80
description: A French actor, he was a heartthrob in the musical “The Young Girls of Rochefort,” a photojournalist in the thriller “Z” and a jaded director in the hit “Cinema Paradiso.”
content: Jacques Perrin, a comely and soft-spoken veteran French actor — he didn’t smolder so much as twinkle — who went from starring in musical and dramatic films to directing and producing them, most notably the political thrillers of Costa-Gavras and his own poetic documentaries about the natural world, died on April 21 in Paris. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Spiral
description: Will Shortz finally circles back with a new Spiral puzzle.
content: SPIRAL — We haven’t seen this elegant type of puzzle in the Times in over a year, and I know that everyone has been eagerly awaiting the return of the Spiral. It is definitely one of my favorites in the rotation of sporadic challenges. The puzzle is beguilingly simple to explain: A spiraling string of 100 boxes is filled in by two sets of clues, one winding from the outer edge of a circle (box No. 1) to its center (100), the other starting in the center and working its way out. Every letter in the string appears in each set of clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
title: A Body Bag and a Sister in Denial
description: The war in Ukraine is so big that it has shaken the world. But for a sister looking for her missing older brother, it was reduced to a visit to a morgue.
content: ZMIIV, Ukraine — The wind carried the smell of death across the street. The body of the dead man, burned, mutilated and barely recognizable, was taken from the refrigerator and laid on a metal gurney. The coroner smoked a cigarette and unzipped the black bag.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amanda Serrano and Katie Taylor Are Ready to Box Their Way Into History

content: Joe Frazier vs. Muhammad Ali. Evander Holyfield vs. Mike Tyson. Deontay Wilder vs. Tyson Fury. Katie Taylor vs. Amanda Serrano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: In ‘Jerusalem,’ a Once-in-a-Lifetime Performance, Again
description: Mark Rylance is back in a role that won him a Tony more than a decade ago. But this London production isn’t just coasting on past kudos.
content: LONDON — There’s mighty, and then there’s Mark Rylance in “Jerusalem,” a performance so powerfully connected to its part that it feels almost superhuman. That’s as it should be for a play about a larger-than-life character named Johnny Byron, who demands an entirely fearless actor, and has one in Rylance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Airbnb tells employees they can work remotely forever.
description: The company, a proponent of more flexible workplace models, previously set a September 2022 date for a return to its offices.
content: Airbnb told its 6,000 employees on Thursday that they would have the option to permanently work remotely, joining a growing number of companies that have ditched return-to-office plans, including Zillow and PwC. Airbnb also told its U.S. employees that they could move to anywhere in the country without a reduction to their compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Solar Industry ‘Frozen’ as Biden Administration Investigates China

content: Plans to install 60 square kilometers of solar panels in Vermont are suddenly on hold.

title: National Security Surveillance on U.S. Soil Dropped Again in 2021, Report Says
description: The F.B.I. also tried to estimate the number of its searches for U.S. data in messages gathered without a warrant. But the estimate — fewer than 3.4 million — was murky.
content: WASHINGTON — Court-approved national security surveillance on domestic soil fell for the third straight year in 2021, extending a trend that has coincided with the decline of the Islamic State, the rise of the coronavirus pandemic and the tightening of procedures after the F.B.I.’s botching of wiretap applications in the Trump-Russia investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Vaccines for Young Children
description: The federal government is telling us two different stories.
content: Why hasn’t the F.D.A. approved a Covid-19 vaccine for children under 5? Government officials have given two conflicting answers in recent days — one that places responsibility on vaccine manufacturers, another that casts the lack of approval as a deliberate federal policy.

content: April wound up being the worst month for Wall Street since the March 2020 panic over the coronavirus, capped by a plunge in stocks on Friday.

title: A Text a Day Kept Other Suitors Away
description: Shortly after Kavya Naini and Eric Elofson met, he left for a two-month work trip. With regular text messages, Mr. Elofson kept their early spark alive.
content: By the time he planned his fourth proposal to Kavya Lakshmi Reddy Naini, Eric Richard Elofson was well aware of the power of persistence. Soon after they started dating in 2017, he had to take a two-month trip to Asia for work and sent her text messages almost every day while he was away.

title: Catherine Spaak, Darling of Italian Cinema in the ’60s, Dies at 77
description: Born in France, she moved to Italy as a teenager and began a long acting career, which extended to Hollywood in the movie “Hotel.”
content: Catherine Spaak, a French-born actress who made her name crossing genres in Italian, French and occasionally American films, acting alongside stars like Jane Fonda and Rod Taylor, died on April 17 in Rome. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wonking Out: Education Has Less to Do With Inequality Than You Think
description: College debtors aren’t a privileged class.
content: President Biden says that he is taking a “hard look” at student debt relief, which probably means that some significant relief is coming. Vance hollered at a rally for Donald Trump in Ohio last weekend. “You cannot have a real country if a bunch of corrupt scumbags who take their marching orders from the Communist Chinese tell us what we’re allowed to say and how we’re allowed to say it.”

title: Watch These 12 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in May

author: By Judith Flanders
title: Fighting for Her Dignity, and Her Children, at the Cost of Her Reputation
description: Antonia Fraser’s “The Case of the Married Woman” tells the story of Caroline Norton, who scandalized 19th-century London society — and upended its laws.
content: Many modern women may well remember a time when they could not open a bank account, or sign for a mortgage, without a countersignature from their husband or father. Antonia Fraser, in her 90th year, certainly will. What none of us, happily, can remember is the time when married women had no legal status at all. Once a woman married, her legal identity was subsumed into that of her husband. A married woman could not sign a contract, nor draw up a will. She had no debts — which sounds great, until you realize that she could not owe money, because all her money, even that she earned herself, belonged to her husband, as did all her possessions. As did her children.

title: Is the U.S. Economy Headed for a Slowdown?
description: A shrinking G.D.P., Amazon’s slowing revenue and supply chain woes all point to the economic engine shifting down a gear.
content: Those looking for signs that the U.S. economy is slowing had plenty to gawk at yesterday. G.D.P. shrank in the first quarter, for the first time since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic. Amazon said its revenue rose at the slowest pace since the dot-com bust. title: 2 on Subway Tracks Killed by Train at a Manhattan Station
description: The deaths came a week after the bodies of two French graffiti artists who had been fatally struck by a train were found in Brooklyn.

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: The Prosecutor Who Put John Gotti Away Explains How He Did It
description: John Gleeson’s “The Gotti Wars” is a memoir about what it took to jail America’s star gangster.
content: Overshadowed by Will Smith’s infamous slap at this year’s Oscars ceremony was a tribute to “The Godfather” on its 50th anniversary. That self-image is, of course, nonsense in real life. John Gleeson, a federal prosecutor later turned federal judge, makes that amply clear in this dissection of how he took on the country’s star gangster of the not-distant past, John Gotti, and packed him off to prison for good.

description: Companies may have lost their showroom hub, but low rents in Midtown, caused by the pandemic, allowed many of them to relocate.
content: In 1992, Arthur Tauber hauled 26 buckets of sand into his showroom at the Textile Building to promote a new collection of beach towels. Another time, his company set up a big, clattering factory-style sewing machine in the lobby, so visitors could watch it embroider multiple towels simultaneously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Education Panel Gets Feisty With the Mayor
description: The Panel for Education Policy balked at passing the Department of Education’s school funding formula for next year.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at an education panel that blocked New York City’s plan for allocating $10.5 billion in school funding. We’ll also look at the prospects for a raise for a small but important group of lawyers who haven’t had one since 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Antisemitism Increased Under Trump. Then It Got Even Worse.
description: The worldwide growth of a social crisis.
content: The Anti-Defamation League this week released a report showing that in 2021, there were more antisemitic incidents in America than in any other year since the group started keeping track over 40 years ago. “We’ve never seen data like this before, ever,” Jonathan Greenblatt, national director of the A.D.L., told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: A Different Kind of California Playlist
description: We’re debuting a new soundtrack dedicated to ambivalence, if not outright disdain, for the Golden State.
content: We Californians tend to get a little starry-eyed when talking about our home state, hung up on the rewards of living in a coastal paradise instead of the rougher reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: With ‘Only One to Choose From,’ a Great Choice
description: Before meeting at a party in 2011, Michael Taylor and Tim Vincent both thought they would be single for life.
content: Michael Taylor is the rare person who can say that much of what he’s learned about long-term relationships was on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Why Ramadan Generates Millions in Charitable Giving Every Year
description: During the Muslim holy month, there is a strong focus on helping others.
content: Muhammad Harby fasts from sunrise to sunset during the holy month of Ramadan. Then, after he breaks his fast, he heads from Brooklyn to Midtown Manhattan every day for a late night appointment with hundreds of homeless New Yorkers who rely on him and other Muslim volunteers for a hot meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Just You and Me, Baby
description: Erica Hsiung Wojcik makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some people like to solve crossword puzzles first thing in the morning, and some people like to solve them before they go to bed. I am a midday solver, and I’ll tell you why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Halfway Home’ and ‘The Code Breaker’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: HALFWAY HOME: Race, Punishment, and the Afterlife of Mass Incarceration, by Reuben Jonathan Miller. (Back Bay, 352 pp., $18.99.) To learn how former inmates navigate life after prison, Miller, an associate professor at the University of Chicago, interviewed nearly 250 people and combines case studies with memoir to offer a wide view on incarceration in America. “A combination of scholarly insight and firsthand pain lends force to this book,” our reviewer, Michael O’Donnell, commented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: A Georgia City Reckons With a New District, Led by Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: Powder Springs is one of two predominantly Black suburbs drawn into the far-right Republican’s district. If Ms. Greene is their voice in Congress, will she speak for them?
content: POWDER SPRINGS, Ga. — Less than a 30-minute drive from Atlanta, Powder Springs embodies the changes reshaping Georgia politics. Shops and restaurants owned almost entirely by Black proprietors line its downtown center and are frequented by a growing population of young and racially diverse residents. The suburban city elected its first Black mayor in 2015, and the county where it sits, the former Republican stronghold of Cobb, voted for President Biden by 14 percentage points in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Stafford
title: A Black Man Ran to Gay Enclaves to Feel Safe. But Was He Welcome?
description: Zach Stafford, the former editor in chief of The Advocate, traveled to gay safe havens as he has for so many summers, but the summer of 2020 was different.
content: Just days after the pandemic made landfall in New York City in the spring of 2020 — and right as the city streets became ghostly reminders of what was — I began to run every morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: During Ramadan, Palestinians Barred From Aqsa Turn to Smugglers
description: For Palestinian Muslims, praying at the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem is an important part of Ramadan. Those barred by Israel are finding ways to get there anyway.
content: JERUSALEM — Only moonlight cut through the darkness early one recent morning by the time a smuggler led Husam Misk to a ladder propped against Israel’s concrete separation barrier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: 10 Years After Sandy, Fire Island’s Fragile Beaches Are Holding Up
description: A $170 million effort by the federal government helped the island recover in the aftermath of the 2012 hurricane, but residents recognize that another storm could wash all the progress away.
content: After Hurricane Sandy ravaged the Eastern Seaboard in 2012, Jared Della Valle took action. The storm had destroyed one of his homes on Fire Island, a narrow strip of land off Long Island, and damaged another. So he decided it was time to move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report big jump in profits because of higher oil and gas prices.
description: Despite pleas from the Biden administration for more supply, both companies said their global production fell in the first three months of the year.
content: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. oil companies, on Friday reported a second consecutive quarter of robust earnings as oil and natural gas prices continued to rise after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Sasha Waltz’s Action Painting Swirls to ‘In C’
description: Waltz’s dance to Terry Riley’s seminal score, at the Brooklyn Academy, is loose and cheerful, giving a spatial sense of the suspension of time.
content: The directions for Terry Riley’s seminal 1964 composition “In C” are fairly simple. The single-page score consists of 53 short musical motifs, which the musicians play in order. But since each musician chooses how many times to repeat each figure before progressing to the next, there’s a continual shifting of alignment and displacement. That, combined with the unceasing, metronomic ticking of a C note, creates a tension between staying in place and moving on. It’s the sound of collective decision-making, the harmonious kind, more buzzing beehive than rowdy town-hall meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Trevor Bauer Suspended for Two Seasons Amid Abuse Claim
description: Bauer, a pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, had been on leave from the club as he faced allegations of sexual assault. Prosecutors in Los Angeles had declined to charge him criminally.
content: Trevor Bauer of the Los Angeles Dodgers has been suspended by Major League Baseball for two seasons, effective immediately, for violating the league’s domestic violence and sexual assault policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Is Australian Democracy in Decline?
description: With a federal election just a few weeks away, it’s time to put Australia’s system and political flaws into context.
content: I’ve been thinking a lot about that question lately, after reporting on what’s needed to strengthen the liberal world order after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and as Australia’s campaign season has intensified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: Thomas Adès Charts a Journey Through Hell and Heaven
description: At the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the composer’s “Dante” is an extreme rarity in orchestral music: a new evening-length work.
content: LOS ANGELES — Step into Walt Disney Concert Hall here this weekend, and you’ll find one of the rarest creatures in classical music: a new evening-length work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Why Netflix Is the Worst Performing Stock in the S&P 500
description: Shares in Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft have all fallen this year, but Netflix has come in for the harshest punishment.
content: Netflix has been an amazing innovator and an extravagant spender. And if you forget that it borrowed billions to finance two decades of exponential growth, the company would be a resounding success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The N.F.L. Draft Fashion Scorecard
description: It may be the last bastion of raw red carpet self-expression.
content: Is it possible the last red carpet that is genuinely a place of self-expression rather than big brand fashion marketing belongs to the N.F.L. draft?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: The ‘Ultimate Bird’ Once Prowled the Seas of a Young Japan
description: Researchers described Annakacygna, a family of flightless ancient swans that were filter-feeders.
content: It’s not unusual today to find swans on rivers and lakes, splitting their time between pulling up water plants and punishing the unwise with powerful blows of their bony-elbowed wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Maggie Astor
title: Why Americans Became More Vulnerable to Oil Price Spikes
description: When prices soared years ago, Americans launched broad efforts to wean the nation off oil and gas to protect households from price swings. But then supply rose and plans fizzled.
content: More than a decade ago, when Americans faced surging prices at the pump, policymakers developed a vision to wean people off gas and oil: more efficient cars, more compact and walkable communities, more renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney’s top communications executive is out after less than four months.
description: Geoff Morrell’s brief tenure was defined by the company’s being drawn into the partisan political fray, most notably in Florida.
content: Disney parted ways with its most senior communications and government relations executive on Friday after a tumultuous two-month period in which Disney became a political punching bag, particularly for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niela Orr
title: Michael R. Jackson’s Big Broadway Thriller
description: With his bravura meta-musical, “A Strange Loop,” the playwright is showing Broadway audiences something they have never seen before.
content: During a walk along the Great White Way this winter, I saw something peculiar: two marquees advertising two Michael Jacksons. On 52nd Street, at the Neil Simon Theater, where “MJ: The Musical” has been running since December, there’s a graphic of the King of Pop in his iconic early ’90s pose: fedora perched low, obscuring his face; shirttails flying in the artificial wind; white glove; high-water pants; sparkling socks; feet en pointe. Seven blocks away, at the Lyceum Theater on 45th Street, another sign bore the name “Michael Jackson” and an illustration of a 20-something Black man’s head in semi-profile, with six tiny bodies floating around his face and hair. This image advertised “A Strange Loop,” the playwright Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning metafictional musical, which premiered on Broadway in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Text Neck, Pinkie Pain and Other Ways Phones Can Wreck Our Bodies
description: Health providers say they are seeing more patients than ever with pain and joint ailments in their hands, necks, shoulders and upper backs — and that mobile phones are most likely playing a part.
content: A few years ago, my best friend texted me to confess that she was worried about her texting. Her hands and fingers ached throughout the day, and the pain worsened when she used her smartphone. Could our incessant texting about parenting and politics be the culprit?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In a New ‘Macbeth,’ Something Wonky This Way Comes
description: Daniel Craig and Ruth Negga star in Sam Gold’s oddly uneasy take on the Scottish play.
content: Macbeth, the character, is full of compunction, as well he should be, having murdered a king to get to his throne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: In Echo of Soviet Era, Russia’s Movie Theaters Turn to Pirate Screenings
description: In a Cold War throwback, some venues are showing bootleg versions after Hollywood studios pulled films from the country. Still, viewer numbers have tanked.
content: Since the invasion of Ukraine, Hollywood’s biggest studios have stopped releasing movies in Russia, and Netflix has ceased service there. But recently, some of the companies’ films have started appearing in Russian movie theaters — illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Cahalan and Adeel Hassan
title: Cases are rising in nearly every corner of the United States.
description: Hospitalizations remain low, partly a reflection of greater immunity in the population.
content: Coronavirus cases and hospitalizations are rising in a majority of American states, in what appears to be the first widespread increase since the peak of the Omicron surge in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Aronoff
title: We’ve Opened the Door Too Wide for Oil and Gas Companies
description: Government support could be the deciding factor in whether a new generation of climate-damaging infrastructure gets built.
content: Policymakers in the United States seem stuck in a bind. To alleviate a potentially catastrophic energy crisis in Europe, more U.S. oil and gas will need to flow there to replace Russian fuel. To make that happen, companies and politicians on both sides of the aisle are clamoring to boost drilling and fast-track new infrastructure. Americans, meanwhile, want cheaper gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Started Out as a Fish. How Did It End Up Like This?
description: A meme about the transitional fossil Tiktaalik argues that although we did come out of the sea, we aren’t doing just fine.
content: It may not be the worst of times, but it is certainly not the best of times. The pandemic has no end in sight. The world is warming, the seas are rising and polar bears are barreling toward extinction. Also: taxes, the 9-to-5 workweek, the renewed threat of nuclear war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Extremely Critical Fire Weather’ Threatens the Southwest
description: Parts of the region — including large swaths of New Mexico — have been seared by drought and raked by high winds, fueling existing wildfires and creating ideal conditions for new ones.
content: A large swath of the United States faced twin weather threats on Friday as a severe drought turned parts of the Southwest into a tinderbox, ripe for more wildfires, and powerful storms threatened to produce tornadoes and hail across the Central Plains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: 8,000 British troops will join allied exercises in Europe, officials say.
description: The troops will serve in the British-led Joint Expeditionary Force, created in 2014 in response to Russia’s seizure of Crimea from Ukraine.
content: The British military will send some 8,000 troops to Europe as part of a larger allied deployment to deter further Russian aggression, British officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Lananh Nguyen
title: Likelihood of Trump Indictment in Manhattan Fades as Grand Jury Wraps Up
description: The Manhattan district attorney is continuing to investigate Donald J. Trump, but knowledgeable people say charges are unlikely to occur in the foreseeable future, if ever.
content: When some two dozen New Yorkers filed into a Manhattan courthouse this week to finish out their grand jury service, the case against a man who would have been the world’s most prominent criminal defendant was no longer before them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Models Have Been Exploited Forever. Can a Law Change Anything?
description: The Fashion Workers Act, a bill working its way through the New York Legislature, takes on a largely unregulated industry.
content: On Monday night, the fashion world will gather for the Met Gala, the annual ritual of celebrity opulence that our current social revolution has not yet harpooned. The theme this year is the evolution of American style, an exploration not only of the work of historically significant designers like Charles James and Halston but also of the dressmakers and tailors who toiled in obscurity on their behalf. The egalitarian dabbling would seem to begin and end there, however, given that the party’s dress code this year is “gilded glamour.” Guests, according to Vogue, whose editor Anna Wintour famously presides over the event, have been asked to “embody the grandeur — and perhaps the dichotomy — of Gilded Age New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Philip J. Hilts, 74, Dies; Reporter Exposed a Big-Tobacco Cover-up
description: In one of many scoops for The Times, he revealed how the tobacco industry had kept secret its own research showing that nicotine was harmful and addictive.
content: Philip J. Hilts, who as a science reporter for The New York Times in 1994 exposed a tobacco company’s decades-long cover-up of its own research showing that tobacco was harmful and nicotine was addictive, died on April 23  in Lebanon, N.H. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Saving the History of the Pines on Fire Island
description: Bobby Bonanno created the Fire Island Pines Historical Preservation Society, collecting photographs and documents and conducting interviews.
content: Erosion is a theme of the Pines, with its wind-tortured dunes and combustible wood buildings. But Bobby Bonanno, 65, who works as a hairdresser in Bellport, N.Y., and has visited the Pines for more than four decades, was concerned about the erosion of memory. To protect the heritage of the Pines, the affluent, largely L.G.B.T.Q. hamlet near the center of Fire Island, he decided to create the Fire Island Pines Historical Preservation Society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Family Court Lawyers Flee Low-Paying Jobs. Parents and Children Suffer.
description: New York hasn’t raised the attorneys’ fees since 2004, creating a shortage that has denied the most vulnerable their constitutional right to a lawyer.
content: For the past two years, Amanda Sanchez’s right to see her young son has depended on the crowded calendar of Helen Bua, the lawyer appointed to represent her in New York’s family court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Rysman
title: When a Restaurant Is a Work of Art
description: Carsten Höller’s latest work is a dining establishment, a social experiment — and a celebrity magnet.
content: STOCKHOLM — “Can somebody dim the Dan Flavin?” It’s not a request one generally hears at a restaurant, but on the inaugural preview night at Brutalisten, the artist Carsten Höller was pulling cords from their sockets at random, still working out a few kinks at his restaurant, including toning down the glaring fluorescent tubes of the Minimalist masterpiece on the dining room’s wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Leader of E.U. Border Agency Departs After Accusations of Abuses During His Tenure
description: The head of the agency, which became emblematic of the bloc’s hardening migration policy, has faced mounting allegations of mismanagement, harassment and human rights abuses at Europe’s borders.
content: BRUSSELS — When Fabrice Leggeri, a French civil servant, took over the European border agency known as Frontex in 2015, its operations were based out of a small office in Warsaw that mostly did administrative work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Coupled by Chance, Then by Choice
description: Alexandra Walsh and Dr. Ben Nguyen forged a connection after being paired as a team of volunteer E.M.T.s. Years later, they started to date.
content: Long before Alexandra Christine Walsh, a physician assistant, and Dr. Ben Anthony Nguyen were joining other health care professionals on the front lines in the fight against the coronavirus, the two were a dynamic duo helping to save lives for the Branchville volunteer fire company in College Park, Md.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Ridley Road’ Review: Undercover With the Neo-Nazis
description: An intrepid young Jewish woman gets cozy with the enemy in a PBS drama that explores a little-known corner of British history.
content: It might seem as if there couldn’t be any nook or cranny of British history that hasn’t received its own television costume drama by now. But “Ridley Road,” premiering Sunday on PBS’s “Masterpiece,” finds some new and interesting territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melani Robinson
title: From Russia With Mixed Feelings
description: I begged my husband to leave Rostov-on-Don. Now I would give anything to be back there with him.
content: Seventeen years ago, my husband and I lived for a time in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, which was then only a short drive across the border from Mariupol, Ukraine, the city currently being decimated by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Consumed by Ambition, Trevor Bauer Must Answer for His Behavior
description: Bauer had said his unhappiness came from always striving for new goals. With a two-year suspension over sexual assault allegations, M.L.B. is moving on without him.
content: This was before his biggest dreams began to blossom, and before his career fell apart. This was Trevor Bauer from three years ago, over lunch in suburban Cleveland, describing the forces that drove him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Superclubs and Spring Nights
description: The Champions League’s late-stage drama is a feature, not a bug. Let’s hope no one messes that up.
content: The nights happen so often now that the possibility they are a coincidence can be safely discounted. They occur with such startling regularity that they do not really count as rare, not anymore. They still possess the texture and the echo of an exception, but by this stage they are better thought of as part of the rule. They are a feature, not a quirk in the code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Sam Smith’s Ode to Self-Acceptance, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Regina Spektor, Tokischa, Wilco and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Jaguars Take Travon Walker With the No. 1 Draft Pick
description: Jacksonville took the defensive lineman after selecting quarterback Trevor Lawrence first overall in 2021.
content: The Jacksonville Jaguars selected Georgia edge rusher Travon Walker with the No. 1 overall pick, hoping the defensive stalwart can pair with quarterback Trevor Lawrence to steer the franchise back to relevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: James Corden Announces He’s Leaving Late Night
description: Corden made an emotional address on Thursday night, saying he never wanted to overstay his welcome.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Ziwe and Her Comedy Pals Party in Pink
description: The comedian celebrated Season 2 of Showtime’s “Ziwe.”
content: Subtlety is not Ziwe’s strong suit. The comedian, talk show host and writer, whose full name is Ziwerekoru Fumudoh, is known for asking very unsubtle, squirm-inducing questions of her guests, first on “Baited with Ziwe,” her YouTube talk series, and now on Showtime’s “Ziwe,” a variety and talk show that celebrated its second season with a party on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: The Office Beckons. Time for Your Sharpest ‘Power Casual.’
description: Work wear reflects how people feel about their jobs and the economy as a whole. So it makes sense that dressing for the office is all over the place.
content: Instagram ads for one brand are touting a style known as “power casual.” Other retailers are calling it “business comfort” or “workleisure.” Heels are dropping lower or disappearing altogether, pants are getting “elasticized,” and Silicon Valley executives are throwing graphic T-shirts under blazers to smuggle a version of self-expression into a board meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: A Chateau of Convenience
description: In the penultimate episode of this season, anything the crew needs from the plot to move forward, it gets.
content: The most interesting revelation in this week’s “Picard” comes in a throwaway line from Seven, in which she tells Raffi that she tried to join Starfleet after Voyager returned from the Delta Quadrant. That Captain Janeway — or possibly Admiral, depending on the timing of her promotion that we saw in “Star Trek: Nemesis” — went to bat for her. Starfleet said no, because of her Borg background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include demented cultists, zombies with pause buttons, hellish stays at a hotel, an unsettling home share and a killer named Oopsie.
content: I’m not a huge zombie fan, but this taut Spanish-language film from the Uruguayan director Gustavo Hernández is an assured and surprisingly artful take on undead mayhem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An ‘Angel’ for Homeless Students and the Revolt of the College-Educated Working Class: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should I Dress for Vacation Like a Travel Influencer?
description: A reader wonders whether comfort or fashion should come first.
content: There is so much to unpack in this question: the way social media has skewed our perceptions of self, the effect of influencer marketing and what to wear when you are seeing the world. Where to start?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! I Spent a Fortune for a Credit-Card Companion Pass But the Virus Wouldn’t Quit
description: Are travelers missing out by not playing the credit-card game in search of first-class tickets? Our new Tripped Up columnist considers the fees and the benefits of two cards.
content: In 2020, my wife and I received a “Travel Together Ticket” from British Airways through a credit card offer and used it — along with 255,000 miles and $2,378 in taxes and fees — to book a flight from Washington to Hong Kong via London. The real value was in two first-class seats on the leg from London to Hong Kong. But the pandemic refused to quit and we exchanged our tickets for travel vouchers good through September 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Anglo-Saxon Kings Made Sure to Eat Their Vegetables, Study Shows
description: Contrary to popular belief, the ruling classes gorged on meat only on rare occasions, according to an analysis of more than 2,000 skeletons buried during medieval times.
content: Anglo-Saxon kings have long reigned in the popular imagination as rapacious meat lovers, eagerly feasting on thick slabs of mutton and beef, washed down with copious amounts of mead and ale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: At an Extra-Credit Assignment, Romance Was an Added Bonus
description: Andrew Eversden and Rachel Wertz hit it off when they met as students in Rome, beginning a love story that would unfold over several years and in various countries.
content: While Andrew D’Alton Eversden was studying abroad at the American University of Rome in the fall of 2017, one of his professors offered students extra credit for volunteering. He chose to do so at a meet-and-greet event with a local refugee center, which was how he found himself waiting outside an Italian government building in the city on a September afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Weighing Risk When the Reporting Is Dangerous
description: A security team watches out for Times journalists abroad. There are strategies in place, but sometimes there’s no other choice but to leave a country.
content: In early March, Anton Troianovski, The Times’s Moscow bureau chief, working closely with newsroom leadership, decided he should leave Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In El Salvador, Relief Over Gang Crackdowns Even as Civil Liberties Suffer
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 29, 2022.
content: “People say, ‘Well, if I am going from being in the authoritarian and homicidal hands of the gang to being in the authoritarian hands of the state, I’ll take it.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Minnesota candidate was in labor during her convention speech. The proceedings went on.
description: Videos of Erin Maye Quade’s speech ricocheted across the internet, with critics saying the process should have been suspended.
content: The pause, three minutes into a candidate’s speech about the toll of climate change, the pandemic and the murder of George Floyd, was not just for rhetorical effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Boris Becker Sentenced to Two and a Half Years for Hiding Assets in Bankruptcy
description: The former tennis champion was found guilty by a London court on charges related to his 2017 insolvency.
content: LONDON — Boris Becker, the six-time Grand Slam tennis champion, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday in his bankruptcy case, after he was found guilty by a London court of hiding millions of dollars’ worth of assets and loans to avoid paying his debts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. sets aside June for potential decisions on vaccines for the youngest Americans.
description: Both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech have asked the agency to approve their vaccines for the youngest children.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration laid out a tentative timetable on Friday for deciding whether to authorize a coronavirus vaccine for America’s youngest children, announcing that June 8 is the earliest date that it will present data to its outside advisers for a recommendation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Elon Musk Might Break Twitter. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
description: The Twitter bid is a power play in the attention economy.
content: If Elon Musk’s bid to purchase Twitter comes to fruition, the world’s richest person will own one of its most important communications platforms. Twitter might have a smaller user base than Facebook, Instagram and even Snapchat, but it shapes the dominant narratives in key industries like politics, media, finance and technology more than any other platform. Attention — particularly that of elite leaders in these industries — is a valuable resource, one that Twitter manages and trades in.

title: This Crispy Fish Is Irresistible
description: Kay Chun’s fish Milanese is topped with a lemony caper sauce, and makes for excellent sandwiches the next day.
content: There are some types of dishes you find the world over. They have different names on their passports and come in diverging styles, but they share delicious fundamentals. The breaded cutlet — known aliases include katsu, schnitzel and Milanesa — is one of them, and a favorite of mine. So I was in heaven when I had chicken Milanese last week at a restaurant, the first one I’ve had in a while, the cutlet golden and crisp, a wild heap of arugula salad on top and a jaunty lemon wedge on the side. It’s a full meal, and a perfect one at that.
